contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist |name = Professor Frederick Kipping |image = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1863|8|16|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Manchester]], [[England]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1949|5|1|1863|8|16|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Criccieth]], [[Caernarfonshire]] (now [[Gwynedd]],) [[Wales]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] |ethnicity = |field = [[chemistry]] |work_institutions = [[University of Nottingham]] |alma_mater = [[University of London]] (1882)<br/>[[Munich University]] (1887) |doctoral_advisor = [[William Henry Perkin, Jr.]] |doctoral_students = |known_for = Work with [[Silicone]] |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = }} Professor '''Frederick Stanley Kipping''' [[Royal Society|FRS]]<ref name="frs">{{cite doi|10.1098/rsbm.1950.0013}}</ref> (16 Aug 1863 - 1 May 1949) was an [[English people|English]] [[chemist]]. He was born in [[Manchester]], [[England]], the son of James Kipping, a Bank of England official, and educated at [[Manchester Grammar School]] before enrolling in 1879 at Owens College (now Manchester University) for an external degree from the [[University of London]]. After working for the local gas company for a short time he went in 1886 to [[Germany]] to work under [[William Henry Perkin, Jr.]] in the laboratories of [[Adolf von Baeyer]] at [[Munich University]]. Back in England, he took a position as demonstrator for Perkin, who had been appointed professor at [[Heriot-Watt University|Heriot-Watt College, Edinburgh]]. In 1890, Kipping was appointed chief demonstrator in chemistry for the [[City and Guilds of London Institute]], where he worked for the chemist [[Henry Edward Armstrong]]. In 1897 he moved to [[Nottingham University|University College, Nottingham]] as professor of the chemistry department, and became the first newly endowed Sir [[Jesse Boot]] professor of chemistry at the university in 1928. He remained there until his retirement in 1936.<ref>{{cite doi|10.1093/ref:odnb/34335}}</ref> Kipping undertook much of the pioneering work into the development of [[silicon]] [[polymers]] ([[silicone]]s) at Nottingham. He pioneered the study of the [[organic compounds]] of silicon ([[organosilicon]]) and coined the term [[silicone]].<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0VJD6MzH9D8C&pg=PT27|page=27|title=Handbook of Sealant Technology|author=K.L. Mittal, A. Pizzi|publisher=CRC Press|year=2009|isbn=0-8493-9162-8}}</ref> His research formed the basis for the worldwide development of the synthetic [[rubber]] and silicone-based [[lubricant]] industries.<ref>Asimov, ''[[Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology]]'' 2nd Revised edition</ref> He also co-wrote, with Perkin, a standard textbook in organic chemistry (''Organic Chemistry'', Perkin and Kipping, 1899). He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in June, 1897.<ref name="frs"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www2.royalsociety.org/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqDb=Persons&dsqPos=0&dsqSearch=%28Surname%3D%27kipping%27%29 | title = Library and Archive catalogue|accessdate= 8 November 2010}}</ref> He was awarded their [[Davy Medal]] in 1918 and delivered their [[Bakerian Lecture]] in 1936. He retired in 1936 and died in Criccieth, Wales. He had married in 1888 Lilian Holland, one of three sisters. Both his brothers-in-law were eminent scientists themselves ([[Arthur Lapworth]] and [[William Henry Perkin, Jr.]]) ==See also== *[[Silicon]] *[[Silicone]] *[[Siloxane]] *[[Organosilicon]] *[[Silicone grease]] *[[Silicone oil]] *[[Silicone resin]] *[[Silicone rubber]] ==References== <references /> ==External links== *[http://www.cartage.org.lb/en/themes/biographies/MainBiographies/k/Kipping/1.html Biography of Frederick Kipping] {{Authority control|VIAF=111006963}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Kipping, Frederick Stanley | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 16 August 1863 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Manchester]], [[England]] | DATE OF DEATH = 1 May 1949 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Criccieth]], [[Caernarfonshire]] (now [[Gwynedd]],) [[Wales]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kipping, Frederick Stanley}} [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:People from Manchester]] [[Category:People educated at Manchester Grammar School]] [[Category:English chemists]] [[Category:English academics]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Nottingham]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] {{UK-chemist-stub}}
